Professional Record.
H. R. Carter.

list.item:
Maritime Quarantine: Served as U. S. Quarantine
officer 1888 - 1895 inclusive.
1: Initiated the Maritime Quarantine Sys-
tem of the U. S. and instrumental in its substi-
tution for those of municipalities and States.

2: Inaugurated the Quarantine systems of
Cuba and of the Canal Zone.

Yellow Fever:
3: Represented the U. S. in the manage-
ment of a number of yellow fever epidemics in the
U. S., 1893-99.

item.p:
4: Discovered and formulated of the “extrin-
sic incubation of yellow fever,” pub. May 1900.
This, in conjunction with the work of Major (Sir)
Ronald Ross on the conveyance of malaria was the
foundation for Walter Reed's discovery of the mos-
quito conveyance of yellow fever.

list.item:
5: Assisted in the sanitation of the Panama
Canal, being the ranking officer next to Gorgas
from Dec. 1904 to date of return to the States
(Sept. 1909).

6: Formulated the doctrine of control of
Stegomyia breeding as the sole method for elimi-
nation in endemic centers (Pan American Scientific
Congress, 1908, Santiago de Chile). This is
now universally adopted.

7: Formulated the doctrine of Spontane-
ous Elimination of Yellow Fever by Failure of the
Human Host (1914 & 1917), the basis of much of
our subsequent work for the elimination of yel-
low fever.

8: Investigation of immunity produced by
an attack of yellow fever. (Pan Am. Scien. Con.,
1915. Pub. Annals Trop. Med. & Parasitoloty, Liver-
pool School Trop. Med. 1916).

9: Member Yellow Fever Commission Interna-
tional Health Board of the Rockefeller FoundaO

10: Sanitary Advisor of Peruvian Government,
1920-21: conducting yellow fever campaign in
northern Peru--since his return from Peru his
work in yellow fever has been solely as a con-
sultant and historian.

Malaria:
11: Initiated Malaria Control in the U. S.
(the first place being Roanoke Rapids, N. C. 1913,
which was very successful) and in this work he was
engaged, except when absent from the country,
until 1920.

item.p:
12: Initiated the investigation of the
“impounded waters problem,” i. e. to determine the
effect of the large bodies of impounded water on
the production of malaria and the methods for ob-
viating and controlling the same. This problem
is of great importance to some sections of the Sout
both from an economic and a sanitary standpoint.

No investigation of this subject save
this one has been undertaken either in the U. S.
or abroad.

13: During the World War was in charge of
the control of malaria in the extra-cantonment
areas of the camps east of the Rockies and of the
big industrial plants engaged in the production
of war material.

Since his return from Peru, his work
in malaria has been mainly as a consultant.
